contentrichtext.text: In [[Religion in Mesopotamia|Mesopotamian demonology]], '''Lilin''' were hostile night [[spirits]] that attack men. They had less power than [[Pantheon (gods)|gods]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=D2-Na937xRYC&pg=PA92&dq=Lilitu+Inanna&hl=en#v=onepage&q=Lilitu%20Inanna&f=false The Devil: Perceptions of Evil from Antiquity to Primitive Christianity By Jeffrey Burton Russell]</ref> In [[Jewish mythology]] ''Lilin'' (Hebrew:לילין) is a term for night spirits. In [[Targum Sheni]] Esther 1:3 [[King Solomon]], who commanded all spirits, had the lilin dance before him.<ref>[http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=421&letter=L Jewish Encyclopedia]</ref><ref>[http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/13523-shedim Jewish Encyclopedia]</ref><ref>The Open court, a monthly magazine: Volume 44 1930 "3 The Hebrew word lilin is not a true plural of lilith. We would expecl lilitim or lilitos as a plural. The word is in reality the masculine counterpari of lilith and denotes a male night-monster. presented our common ancestor with a daughter named ..."</ref><ref>The sayings of the Jewish fathers: (Pirke aboth) 1919 "... this is the most general term for them, though various other grades of them are mentioned in the Talmud and kindred writings : shedim = "evil genii," an Assyrio-Bab. loan-word ; lilin, probably evil spirits of the night, also from the Assyrio-Bab.;</ref> In the [[Syriac Apocalypse of Baruch]], ''Lilin'' come from the desert <ref>R H Charles translation</ref> and they are similar to [[shedim]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ZI4pBp-G9csC&pg=PA16&dq=Lilin&hl=en#v=onepage&q=Lilin&f=false The Apocalypse of Baruch]</ref> ==See also== * [[Lilu (mythology)]], Akkadian and Sumerian demons * [[Lilith]], Jewish female demon * [[Lilin in popular culture]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Jewish mythology]] [[Category:Demons in Judaism]] {{Myth-stub}}
